div.p: Memorial of F. C. Gray and others, praying a Bill like that which passed the Senate at the last Session of Congress, of indemnity for French spoliations prior to 1800.— Referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations and printed.
Petition of Albert Pabodie, and 153 citizens of Millbury in the County of Worcester, for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia.

I presented this Petition, and after stating its contents declared my intention to move that it should without reading be laid upon the table— Mr Glascock, interrupting me, moved that the Petition be not received, and proceeded to debate the question— I called him to order, and appealed to the 45th. rule of the House, interdicting debate on petitions, on the day of their presentation— The Speaker decided that the rule did not apply to petitions not received by the House, and that the motion was debateable—from this decision I appealed and asked for the yeas and nays, which were ordered—and a debate followed which consumed the remainder of the day.
The decision upon the appeal from the Speaker’s decision was postponed till next Tuesday—
I presented a Petition of Eunice Clark, widow of Ezra Clark for a remnant of Pension, under the act of 18. March 1818. struck off from the list in 1820.

referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, with a Resolution, instructing the Committee to enquire
into the expediency of restoring all the names of Pensioners of 1818. struck off the list, because they were not in abject poverty.
Petition of the Undersigned, praying for the speedy construction of a Harbour at the Mouth of the River St. Joseph, in the Territory of Michigan.— Novr. 1835
Petition presented, from sundry persons, praying for the construction of a Harbour at the mouth of the river St. Joseph in the Territory of Michigan—
Referred to the Committee on Commerce.
Met the Committee of Manufactures—present. Messrs. Dickerson, M’Comas, Webster, Gideon Lee, Judson, and Holsey— Absent Denny and Granger
Petition of a Railway Canal Company in Georgia, for permission to import two iron boats, free of duty—
Postponed to Tuesday 26—at ten O’Clock

Letter from George White requesting the use of Plates, employed by Dr Mease in preparing his report on Silk—not referred to the Committee— Agreed to offer a Resolution, referring the subject to the Committee
At the House.
I offered the Resolution from the Committee of Manufactures, to refer the subject of Dr Mease’s silk-worm plates, by them, which was adopted.

I presented from the Committee on the Smithson bequest Message, a Bill and Report— The Bill was read twice, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, and with the report were ordered to be printed.
Order of the day— L. Jarvis’s Resolution
January 20. V. Wednesday

House—Mr Chapin moved to take up his Resolution offered yesterday to print 5000 extra copies of the Smithson bequest Message and Report.— Objection made— Mann moved to suspend the rules—carried by more than two thirds— Parker opposes the resolution upon the ground of expense—motion carried without a division— Chapin came and asked me if some note could be introduced into the publication mentioning the name of all the members of the Committee— I said they had only to copy from the Journal of the House the entries of the receipt of the Message and the names of the members of the Committee as ordered by the House and appointed by the Speaker— I spoke to Mr Johnson, the assistant Clerk about it and he said it should be done

First hour— Reports of Committees— Jarvis’s Anti-Abolition resolution; with Glascock’s and Wise’s Amendments. Wise modified again— Bouldin finished his boiling water speech and Pickens began one of molten lead— At the expiration of the hour Cambreleng called for the orders of the day. Question of order decided by the Speaker— Yeas and nays on passing to the orders of the day 105 and 105. Polk Speaker decides to pass— Then all the other orders postponed to take up the New-York sufferers Bill— The partial appropriation Bill postponed till to-morrow— I asked Cambreleng when the general Appropriation Bill would be reported. He said next Tuesday— One of the Clerks was sick— New-York sufferers Bill much opposed— D. J. Pearce’s speech against it left unfinished— Adjourned at1/2 past 3. Rode home— My wife suddenly taken very ill— Mr and Mrs Frye here. Dr Huntt twice— Mr Hawley in the Evening—
Conversation with Mr Slade.

At the Library—Cuthbert—Pope, Homer— At the House— My Appeal from the decision of the Speaker that the 45th. rule, does not apply to the question whether a Petition shall be received, was postponed to this day—a Motion was now passed to postpone it to next Saturday week—which I opposed but it was carried

Called at the Globe Office, with the corrected proof sheet of the Report on the Smithsonian bequest; which the foreman Mr Kincaid promised to have struck off, and my copies laid upon my table to-morrow Morning— He said too the Report should be published next week in the Globe— At the Library of Congress I gave to the Librarian Meehan the Catalogue of the Books of Count Boutourlin—which I had entered as from Richard H. Wilde through my hands— I gave the Book afterwards to Mr Loyall one of the members of the Library Committee on the part of the House— I had some conversation with General Glascock of Georgia, upon the abolition Petitions, and some with D. J. Pearce, who asked me yesterday to offer a Resolution upon the dispute with France— I told him I could not obtrude myself upon the House on that Subject, and that I had done so at the last Session, only because the Committee of Foreign Relations had delayed to Report till I feared the House would do nothing. Caleb Cushing came to speak about the abolition petitions of which he said he had many to present— I told him I should make a point upon the appeal again next Monday— As soon as the Journal was read, Cambreleng read a paragraph from a Newspaper in which he was attacked for the loss of the fortification Bill at the last Session, and said he should take notice of it— Whereupon I asked leave of the House to offer the Resolution to refer that part of the President’s Message to a select Committee with Instructions to enquire and report the causes of the failure of that bill—objection made the suspension of the rules was moved and carried by yeas and naystoI offered my Resolution, and supported it by a speech of nearly three hours— Wise commenced answering it, and after speaking about an hour gave way to a motion for adjournment which was carried— Mr Frye was here this Evening and spoke about the Georgia Lands and the division of T. Hellen’s property His Cloak and Umbrella were stolen from our Entry.

Snow great part of the day— Fell about six inches deep. Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Bishop, from Daniel 5.5—[“]In the same hour came forth a finger of a man’s hand, and wrote over against the candlestick, upon the plaister of the Wall, of the king’s palace: and the king saw the part of the hand that wrote— 6. Then the king’s countenance was changed, and his thoughts troubled him, so that the joints of his loins were loosened and his knees smote one against another.”— The Sermon was upon the power of Conscience; and in Mr Bishops usual style of eloquence— Somewhat declamatory but full of thought, of imagery and of Sentiments— This is one of all the passages of Scripture most impressive upon the imagination— There is something awful and terrific in the fact— Nothing in Romance is so appaling— The hand coming out of the Wall in the midst of a joyous and dissolute banquet, loosens ones loins and makes one’s knees shake almost like those of Belshazzar. The description of the effect of the incident upon the loins and knees of the king is admirable— The application of the whole story to illustrate the power of Conscience upon the actions and sentiments of man was ingenious and instructive— There was no afternoon Service at St. John’s Church. Mrs Frye dined with us and Mary towards dusk accompanied her home— I was all the leisure of the day, revising the report of my Speech by Mr Moore for the Globe—which was very imperfect and which I have not time to dress as it should be dressed— Coll R M Johnson sent me a note yesterday concerning it—and the foreman of the Globe Office informed me that he should print a large pamphlet Edition of it.
Jany. 25. Monday VI:30— Ground covered with snow.

Petition from Citizens of Indiana and Westmoreland Counties Pennsylvania, for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia. I moved it should be received— 370 laid on the table—
Petitions from Western Pennsylvania for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade—70—
Petition of 103 Ladies of Marshfield for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia—

In presenting these Petitions I urged the reasons for their reception— Motions were attempted to lay them on the table— The Speaker again decided that I had a right to debate the question upon their reception— Craig appealed and after sundry other motions to postpone the decision upon my appeal to Saturday Monday and Tuesday, the Previous Question was called and sustained and the decision of the Speaker confirmed by a vote of 141 to 59— I then presented successively two other petitions—the motions to receive which were after debate laid on the table. Next Caleb Cushing presented two similar Petitions and moved they should be received, supporting the motions with short handsome Speeches— Answered by Garland, and after four O’Clock the House adjourned without proceeding further in the presentation of Petitions— Cushing told me that he was not the author of the publication signed Massachusetts in the National Intelligencer of this Morning. On coming home I found my wife exceedingly ill with an attack of Erysipelas as she continued the whole Evening— Dr Huntt was here twice this day—once after my return home.
Met the Committee of Manufactures— Present, Dickerson, Denny, Webster, Judson, Granger— Absent Gideon Lee, M’Comas, and Holsey—

Voted that the Chairman offer a Resolution, authorising the Secretary of the Treasury to make the Sale of the Plates of Dr. Mease’s Treatise on the silk manufacture and deposit the proceeds in the Treasury—

voted that an unfavourable report should be made on the Petition of the Steam Boat Company of Georgia, that they be permitted to import two Iron Steam Boats, free of duty, that the Committee be discharged from the further Consideration of the Petition, and that it be laid on the table— But as Mr Holsey the member from Georgia was absent, I asked leave to see him again and if he desired it to agree to have another Meeting of the Committee before making this report.

At the House on the reading of the Journal.— Hardin asked a correction, stating that his objection yesterday to my presenting a Petition from Pennsylvania, was not that a member from one State had no right to present a petition from another but that a member from Massachusetts could not present a Petition from Pennsylvania before Pennsylvania should be called— I said I had not any objection to the correction of the Journal, if the Speaker himself understood the question, which Hardin made as he now stated it—but he did not so understand it— But Hardin was permitted to have his Statement entered on the Journal of this day—

27. VI:45. Wednesday

At the House, I asked leave of the House to offer a Resolution calling on the President for copies of the Act of the French Chambers of Appropriation for payment of the claims of the Treaty of July 1831.— Objection was made. I asked the reading of the Resolution; but objection was made and I did not move the suspension of the Rules.
